channel.title: Spring
channel.description: Level up your Java code and explore what Spring can do for you.

item.title: This Week in Spring - February 11th, 2025
item.dc:creator: joshlong
item.content:encoded:
Hi, Spring fans! It's almost Valentine's day, and let me just say: I love the Spring community! It's such an exciting and interesting place to be. Thank you everyone for all that you do.

I'm busy preparing for ConFoo, in Montreal, Canada, and for Devnexus, in Atlanta, Georgia. If you're around be sure to stop and say salut or hi!

We've got an amazing lineup for you this weekend, so let's dive right into it.

  • How to create dynamic SQL queries with Spring Boot
  • I love this article looking at the amazing new features in Spring Application Advisor
  • a lovely video by the amazing Greg Turnquist: Using JdbcTemplate with CockroachDB
  • Spring AI: a Doot to GenAI heaven for Java developers - yup!
  • in last week's installment of A Bootiful Podcast, I talked to "Just Use Postgres!" author Denis Magda
  • I've got this queueud up: Spring AI Masterclass with Spring Boot..
  • ..and this one: Spring AI with DeepSeek R1
  • a gentle reminder that there are guides on how to build your first application with Spring Boot available here
  • and don't forget we have the Spring Academy if you want guides courses...

item.title: A Bootiful Podcast: 'Just Use Postgres!' author Denis Magda
item.dc:creator: joshlong
item.content:encoded: Hi, Spring fans! In this installment we talk to Java and distributed database ninja Denis Magda about his new book, "Just Use Postgres!", which looks at how to wield Postgres for a variety of use cases that an application developer should know.

item.title: This Week in Spring - February 4th, 2025
item.dc:creator: joshlong
item.content:encoded:
Hi, Spring fans! Welcome to another installment of This Week in Spring! It's February 4th, 2025, as I write this. We are ten days away from Valentine's day, and about a month away from Devnexus. Lots to look forward to, in both the short term and the long term!

Let's dive right into this week's roundup!

  • Thanks very much to the San Francisco JUG for letting Spring Boot co-founder Phil Webb and I take a little stroll down memory lane, and revisit at the first 10 whole years of Spring Boot. This was a ton of fun!
  • our friend, Vaadin's Marcus Hellberg, has a really crazy example of a Spring Boot and Vaadin application that uses Spring AI MCP to update itself!
  • Bellsoft's Catherine Edelveis has a nice video on Dockerizing your Spring Boot applications
  • do you ever want an exploding code minigame from within your IntelliJ IDEA? there's a plugin for that!
  • Spring Cloud Stream Applications 2024.0.1 and 2025.0.0 are now available
  • in last week's installment of A Bootiful Podcast, I talked to HTMX creator Carson Gross.
  • and just this morning, I had another discussion - but this time intended for Youtube! - with Carson, looking at how to actually weild HTMX and Spring Boot together
  • Spring Boot 3.4 came out in November and brought with it a ton of cool features! Did you see the roundups I did looking at the various portfolio projects, both above and below that release? What's new in Spring AI M4 , What's new in Spring Modulith 1.3, What's new in Spring Batch 5.2, What's new in Spring Integration 6.4, What's new in Spring Security 6.4, What's new in Spring Data 2024.1?, and finally What's new in Spring Framework 6.2

item.title: Spring Cloud Stream Applications 2024.0.1 and 2025.0.0 are now available
item.dc:creator: onobc
item.content:encoded:
On behalf of the team and everyone who has contributed, I’m happy to announce that Spring Cloud Stream Applications 2024.0.1 and 2025.0.0 have been released and are now available from Maven Central.

The releases include numerous bug fixes and dependency upgrades.

The 2024.0.1 release updates to Spring Boot 3.3.8 / Spring Cloud 2023.0.5 and the 2025.0.0 release updates to Spring Boot 3.4.2 and Spring Cloud 2024.0.0.

Please see the release notes (2024.0.1 and 2025.0.0) for more details.

Stay in touch...

Please continue to engage with us by creating bug reports and feature requests on Github and asking questions on StackOverflow using the spring-cloud-stream or spring-cloud-dataflow tags.
